abstract.p: India contributes a large percentage to total world production of rice husk, jute, banana, and coconut fiber. All these natural fibers have excellent physical and mechanical properties, which can be used effectively in the development of composite materials for various structural applications. This article gives an overall view of banana fiber composite and its mechanical properties. The advantage of using natural fiber materials over traditional materials and its possible growth in future are also discussed. The experimental results showed that 15 wt% banana fiber reinforced composite show optimum mechanical properties.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the last few years, there has been intense research on natural fiber composites. These researches show that natural fiber composite exhibits superior properties compared to conventional composites. Numerous studies have shown that the addition of natural fiber reinforcement can lead to a signiﬁcant enhancement of many properties, such as stiffness and strength.1–5 The key to obtaining signiﬁcant property enhancements is by homogenous dispersing of fiber, i.e. the individual banana fiber (BF) within the polymer matrix to take advantage of their high aspect ratio and surface area.6 The affinity between the polymer matrix and BF is determined, to some extent, by the polarity of the functional groups. The affinity of the polymer with the surface of the BF is essential to promote favorable interactions to obtain high-level mechanical properties. All these properties make the materials suitable for a wide variety of applications such as construction, automotive, electronics, packaging, etc.1,7 The development and application of lightweight sandwich structural elements is a growing trend in the construction industry all over the world due to their high strength-to-weight ratio, reduced weight, and good thermal insulation characteristics.8,9 In general, utilization of biomass in lignocellulosic composites brings several advantages such as low density, greater deformability, less abrasiveness to equipment, biodegradability, and low cost.10,11 However, in producing a good lignocellulosic composite, the main obstacle to be resolved is the compatibility between the ﬁbers and the matrix. The properties of the lignocellulosic composites are dominated by the interfacial interaction between the lignocellulosic ﬁbers and the polymer matrix. In this study, the introduction of a novel technique of lightweight sandwich composite element presents new possibilities in the design of polyurethane sandwich composite.

sec.title: Multilayer sandwich model
sec.p:
In this model, we have used thin sheets of polyurethane (indicated by number 1) as an alternative layer in compress molding, which is shown in Figure 2. In between the polyurethane sheets, BF mats (indicated by number 2) are placed as the reinforcing filler, because it acts as a multilayer sandwich technique for our system. We fabricated a total of six types of composite samples: TPU (BF 0%, no BF mat and single polyurethane sheet), TPU-5 (BF 5%, 1 BF mat, and 2 PU sheets), TPU-10 (BF 10%, 2 BF mats, and 3 PU sheets), TPU-15 (BF 15%, 3 BF mats, and 4 PU sheets), TPU-20 (BF 20%, 4 BF mats, and 5 PU sheets), and TPU-25 (BF 25%, 5 BF mats, and 6 PU sheets). The final thickness of the whole composites sample sheet was 4 mm. This sandwich model enhanced the homogeneous distribution of BF in polyurethane base matrix. TPU sheets and fiber mats were stacked and compressed through the process of compression molding. The mechanical properties such as enhancement in stiffness and strength of polyurethane composites may be due to this multilayer sandwich model. To achieve uniform strength in all directions, we developed a BFRP composite with multidirectional orientation of the fibers. BF has maximum strength along the fibers and minimum strength across the fibers.6 Figure 2.
Multilayer sandwich composite model.

sec.title: Preparation of the composite
sec.p: Composites were fabricated using BF by varying fiber loading. The amount of BFs used depends on the number of mats used in the composite. We fabricated a total of six types of composite samples shown in Table 2. The polyurethane layer was evenly spread on the fiber mat before being placed in a mold. The steel mold dimensions were 200 × 200 × 4 mm3. The sheets were compressed on a compression molding machine (Wabash, Carver Inc., Indiana, USA) at a temperature of 190°C and load of 8000 psi. The breathing and compression time were taken to be 1 and 10 min, respectively. Polyurethane sheets were softened by applying temperature and BF mats were immersed in the polyurethane matrix by applying pressure.

The analysis of tensile, flexural, and impact properties of these composites revealed that the optimum loading of fiber is required. BF reinforced composites showed an increase in properties with fiber loading. Thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) green composites were prepared. BFs were used in the form of mats.6,12 The properties of the composites were believed to be predominantly influenced by the type of bonding produced. Fracture toughness of natural ﬁbers and polyurethane composites were investigated. The main interest in studying these biomass composites arise from the fact that both ﬁbers and matrix are derived from renewable resources and the formed composite constitute an important step toward environmental preservation.13,14

sec.title: Mechanical testing
sec.p:
The composite sheet so produced was cut into ﬂexural, tensile, and impact test samples. Tensile testing was done in accordance with ASTM D638, using the same machine and crosshead speed on samples with dimensions of 3.2 × 12.7 × 165 mm3 at 50 mm/min. Flexural testing was conducted according to ASTM D790 using a ZWICK Z010. The three-point bending test was carried out at 50 mm/min crosshead speed on samples with 12.7 × 3.2 × 125 mm3 dimensions.17,18 The samples with dimensions of 12.7 × 3.2 × 58 mm3 were used for Charpy impact tests in accordance with ASTM D256. The impact tests were conducted using an Impact Pendulum Tester (Zwick) model 5101. In each case, a minimum of 10 samples were tested.12
Tensile properties In the case of BF–TPU composites, as the BF content increased, modulus showed an initial rapid increase but then showed only marginal or no change. The tensile strength gradually increases with an increasing amount of BF at the optimum amount in composites. This may be due to the good interfacial adhesion between the polymer matrix and BF.18 Elongation at break decreased significantly upon incorporation of BF. This may be due to the increase in discontinuity of polymer matrix with an increase in the disperse phase (BF). The tensile properties are given in Table 4. The experimental results showed that at 15 wt% BF reinforced TPU composites showed an increase of modulus by 359% (maximum) and then again decreased as BF wt% increased. Tensile strength increased continuously up to TPU-15, and the trend was continued in TPU-20 too; but TPU-25 showed a decrease in tensile strength. Elongation at break decreased continuously with increasing BF loading. In each case, a minimum of 10 samples were tested. Table 4.

Flexural testing result showed that as the BF content increases, modulus first increases rapidly and then shows marginal change. The flexural strength gradually increases with increasing amount of BF in composites. The results of impact strength test showed that as the BF content increases, impact strength increases rapidly and after a point showed a marginal decrease. The experimental results showed that 15 wt% BF sample shows the highest impact strength in BF reinforced TPU composites.18,19 In general, it can be concluded that mechanical properties and durability of natural fiber composites can be enhanced by using the above approach.20 Generally, there are two types of interactions at the interfacial region: primary and secondary bonding include covalent and hydrogen bonding, respectively. Covalent bonding at the interfacial region exists in between the thermoplastic polymer and the fiber. This is because lignocellulosic fiber has hydroxyl (–OH) groups, which could serve as reaction sites with various functional groups in polyurethane. This study indicates that in addition to the ability of the mat to absorb stress transfer, the compatibility between the ﬁber and the matrix may also come into play. This is possible through the reaction of –OH groups of BF with –NCO groups of polyurethane chains (Figure 3). It is a proven fact that –NCO is reactive enough to react with OH of lignocellulosic materials by forming urethane linkages. Figure 3.

sec.title: X-Ray studies
sec.p:
X-ray diffraction was used to study the interplanar distances (d-spacing) in the PU crystalline samples. By the use of Bragg’s equation the d-spacing corresponding to the large peaks in the respective curves were calculated as shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
X-ray study of banana fiber polyurethane composite.

The determination of the amorphous and crystalline nature of the composites was obtained from peak area. The diffractograms exhibited broad peaks at 2θ angles around 11, 20, 22, 24 and 40, indicating degree of crystallinity. These peaks were assigned to scatter from PU chains with regular interplanar spacing. The results obtained by XRD analysis showed TPU crystal structures.

sec.title: NMR studies
sec.p:
By the investigation of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) data, it was confirmed that this composite have (–O–CH2–) groups, as evident by the presence of a peak at 3.3 ppm (Figure 5). Tensile testing results showed that at 15 wt%, tensile modulus, BF reinforced TPU composites increased 359% (maximum) and then showed a decline in tensile modulus. Tensile strength continuously increases up to TPU-15 but remains approximately constant thereafter. With increasing BF loading, elongation at break decreased continuously. Figure 5.
NMR studies of the banana fiber polyurethane composite.
NMR: nuclear magnetic resonance.

sec.title: Morphological characterization
sec.p:
Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) images of BF are shown in Figure 6 where we observe the diameter of BF fiber. SEM Carl Ziess EVO 50 machine was used for the morphological characterization. Cryofractured samples were analyzed by SEM after coating with gold. Based on the experimental results, the following conclusions can be made: the diameter of BF is 80 ± 4 µm calculated by the use of SEM photographs. SEM images shown in Figure 6, illustrate that there is a good adhesion between BFs and polyurethane matrix. When multilayer compression molding process was used, the dispersion of BFs in the matrix was homogeneously distributed and the interaction between BFs and matrix was strong, which corresponds to an improved tensile strength.21 It is known that cellulosic fibers have a cell arrangement, which can divert the crack path by blunting it. Thus the crack does not have a straight path, because it tends to move around the fiber cells and ultimately stops. SEM studies were carried out to evaluate fiber–matrix interactions. The experimental tensile strength was compared with the theoretical predictions. Figure 6.
SEM of the banana fiber (a, b) and polyurethane (c, d) at a magnification 1000×.
SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The structural characteristics of natural fiber composite together with its excellent environmental attributes show its potential as a construction material. The results show that composites with multilayer model have higher modulus than those without layer model ﬁbers composite preparation. This indicates that the multilayer model has resulted in the increased polymer–natural fiber interaction site. They are very well suitable for wall and roof construction. In the present scenario as the environment is degrading and the demand for energy are raising the composites utilizing naturally available fibers provide alternatives to save the environment and diminish energy consumption, which could be needed to process human-made synthetic composites. But, further research and development is required for the extraction and characterization of the basic materials such as fibers to avoid any setback during the transition, i.e. for upscaling of technology from lab scale to the commercial level.
